awd_titl_txt: Surface Stress Relaxation: Science and Effects on Glass Properties
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description: A trace amount of water vapor in the atmosphere can have large effects on mechanical strength of oxide glasses. One important step of this effect is the fast  elimination of the surface stress. This surface stress removal can cause weakening of strengthened glasses. At the same time, the phenomenon can be used to make glass mechanically stronger. The present research can clarify how a trace amount of water can cause these seemingly contradictory phenomena. Research results are discussed in the formal Glass Science course during the academic year, as well as in a "pop-up' short course that includes a broader audience beyond science and engineering during summer sessions. Students - both women and men, and both undergraduates and graduates -trained in this research become valued employees for US high technology companies. 
 
Technical Details: In comparison to bulk glass, oxide glass surfaces (of the same composition) exhibit faster stress relaxation realized by moisture in air. This phenomenon is used to make mechanically stronger glass fibers by building the surface compressive stress caused by the fast surface stress relaxation. The phenomena can also explain long-standing mysteries related to mechanical strength of glasses such as the strength degradation of ion-exchange strengthened glasses, and static fatigue limit. The phenomenon of the fast surface stress relaxation is expected to be important in all amorphous oxides with large surface areas such as thin films, nano-particles and curved surfaces, which readily interact with a trace amount of water vapor. One main objective of the present research is to clarify the scientific origin of the fast surface stress relaxation. The second objective is to optimize the fiber strengthening process and clarify various anomalous features such as anomalous oxidation kinetics of Si with small radius of curvature. During this proposed research, two graduate students and four undergraduate students per year are trained in the glass science field.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcome Report on Award ID-1713670 Surface Stress Relaxation: Science and Effects on Glass Properties.

A glass can have different structures and properties depending upon how it was cooled from its melt. This was attributed to different fictive temperature, the temperature at which a liquid structure froze to turn into a glass.  In our earlier project supported by MSF-DMR, we found that silica glass surface exhibits faster stress and structural relaxation than those of the bulk silica glass, due to the entry of a trace amount of water into the glass surface, and ends with a lower surface fictive temperature under a given cooling rate. This was demonstrated by developing a simple IR method to determine the glass fictive temperature of silica glass bulk and surface, separately, using IR silica structural bands by transmission and reflection, respectively.

We used this phenomenon to produce mechanically stronger silica glass fibers by holding a fiber under a high tensile stress load at low temperatures in low humidity atmosphere. While under a high tensile stress, the surface tensile stress relaxes with the help of low water vapor pressure and upon release of the applied tensile stress, the glass fiber acquires a high compressive surface stress and exhibits higher mechanical strength. An alternative mechanism was proposed by Wiederhorn et al [1]. They attributed the surface compressive stress generated by the heat-treatment in low water vapor pressure was induced by water entry into the glass surface and its swelling. We consider that stress generation of silica glass by water entry requires a large quantity of water, which weakens the silica glass. Furthermore, the swelling of silica glass requires the tensile stresses to expand the glass. In order to demonstrate the stress relaxation, rather than swelling, a shear stress relaxation was tested and demonstrated [2]. Furthermore, birefringence measurement was conducted for both fiber bending and rod torsion samples [3], which showed that stress relaxation rather than swelling is producing strengthening of silica glass fibers. Furthermore, we confirmed that a small quantity of water entry into SiO2 glass surface at low temperatures can induce surface compressive stress of the glass [4].

 

 [1]  S. M. Wiederhorn, F. Yi, D. LaVan, L. J. Richter, T. Fett, and M. J. Hoffmann,  Volume Expansion Caused by Water Penetration into Silica Glass. J. Am. Ceram. Soc. 98 (2015) 78 -86.

[2]. E.M. Aaldenberg, J. S. Aaldenberg, T. A. Blanchet, M. Tomozawa, Surface Shear Stress Relaxation of Silica Glass. J, Am. Ceram. Soc., 102 (2019) 4573 -4581.

[3] B. D. Hausmann, E. M. Aaldenberg, M. Tomozawa, Photo-elastic confirmation of surface stress relaxation in silica glasses: Fiber bending and rod torsion. J. Am. Ceram. Soc., 104 (2021) 3087- 3096.

[4] B. D. Hausmann, M. Tomozawa, Correlation between residual stress and water diffusion into silica glass at low temperatures. J. Am. Ceram. Soc., 106 (2023) 1789-1794.

Modified by: Minoru Tomozawa
